title: 104_hr4004
content: The "401(k) Protection Act of 1996" prohibits qualified employer plans from making loans through credit cards or other intermediaries. This amendment applies to plan years starting after the enactment of the Act. Loans from qualified employer plans are treated as distributions unless used for first home purchase, higher education, financially devastating medical expenses, or during periods of unemployment. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to specify that loans from qualified employer plans are only treated as distributions if used for specific purposes such as first-time homebuyer, higher education, medical expenses, or unemployment. The Internal Revenue Code specifies that a qualified first-time homebuyer loan is any loan used to pay for qualified acquisition costs for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. The term "qualified acquisition costs" refers to the costs of acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement, financing, or closing costs. A "first-time homebuyer" is defined as an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence during the 2-year period before acquiring the principal residence. The term "qualified acquisition costs" include costs of acquiring a residence. A "first-time homebuyer" is someone who had no ownership interest in a principal residence in the 2-year period before acquiring it. The term "principal residence" and "date of acquisition" are defined in relation to section 1034. The term "qualified higher education loan" refers to a loan used for tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment for the individual, spouse, or dependents. The term 'qualified medical expense loan' refers to a loan received by an individual for medical care expenses deductible under section 213. The term 'qualified unemployment loan' refers to a loan received by an individual after separation from employment, if the individual has received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks and the loan is received during the taxable year in which the compensation is paid or the following year. The amendments made by this section apply to loans made after the enactment of this Act.
